name: SADE
description: Scalable Architecture for Digital Editions
contribution_justification: https://gitlab.gwdg.de/SADE/SADE/blob/develop/CONTRIBUTING.md
license_location_justification: https://gitlab.gwdg.de/SADE/SADE/blob/develop/LICENSE
floss_license_justification: The LGPL-3.0-only license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The LGPL-3.0-only license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: We do have a README but no proper user documentation, especially for customization. Furthermore, not all moduls are documented yet.
documentation_interface_justification: It is possible to create docs for all APIs with the eXist-db OpenAPi application, but it's not created by default.
repo_public_justification: https://gitlab.gwdg.de/SADE/SADE
repo_track_justification: Default in GitLab. All changes can by viewed e.g. at https://gitlab.gwdg.de/SADE/SADE/commits/develop.
repo_interim_justification: SADE is developed by using the Git Flow branching model which includes separate branches for features, bugfixes and hotfixes. The develop branch is a stable interim version for review between releases.
repo_distributed_justification: SADE is developed by using git.
version_unique_justification: Each version of SADE is released using Semantic Versioning.
version_tags_justification: Releases are identified via the version number. A tag is added during the Git Flow release process.
release_notes_justification: A change log is provided at https://gitlab.gwdg.de/SADE/SADE/blob/develop/repo.xml.
release_notes_vulns_justification: SADE is an eXist-db app and regularly updated. Possible vulnerabilities only apply to eXist-db.
build_justification: SADE can be built locally by using `ant test`. It also has a separate build environment, https://gitlab.gwdg.de/SADE/build.
build_floss_tools_justification: Since SADE is Open Source, we commit ourselves to use only Open Source tools, too.
test_justification: All tests are executed by a GitLab runner on pushing to develop or master. Results can by viewed in the CI/CD overview (https://gitlab.gwdg.de/SADE/build/pipelines).
test_invocation_justification: Tests are executed from within eXist-db and therefore embedded in the post install directive. Tests can also be invoked by executing `test.xq`.
test_most_justification: Currently tests only cover some of SADE's XQuery module. The existing tests are mainly unit tests; Higher layers of testing aren't implemented yet.
test_policy_justification: Though legacy code doesn't have a full test coverage, the code review process of SADE aims for accepting new functionality as long as it provides documentation and tests.
tests_are_added_justification: This is ensured by code reviews.
static_analysis_justification: XQuery does not have a SAST tool.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: SADE is built continously by a GitLab runner, cf. https://gitlab.gwdg.de/SADE/build/pipelines.
discussion_justification: Issues can be discussed in the issue list in GitLab (https://gitlab.gwdg.de/SADE/SADE/issues). A mailing list is available at https://listserv.gwdg.de/mailman/listinfo/sade.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: SADE stores important credentials outside the database.
english_justification: All documentation is provided in English.
hardened_site_justification: // One or more of the required security hardening headers is missing. // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".

name: sgxwallet
description: sgxwallet is a next generation hardware secure crypto wallet that is based on Intel SGX technology. It currently supports Ethereum and SKALE, and will support Bitcoin in the future.  Sgxwallet is under heavy development and use by SKALE.
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.

build_floss_tools_justification: CMake with entirely free build toolchain (e.g. gcc, clang) can be used for building.

tests_are_added_justification: Tests are added for new functionality.
know_secure_design_justification: The main developer has gone through the relevant texts and practices the mentioned principles to the best of his understanding.
crypto_keylength_justification: TLS default policy requires 2048 bit RSA keys.
crypto_working_justification: Project does not implement RC4, DES, or any other broken or export ciphers.
crypto_random_justification:
A true random function sgx_read_rand is provided in the tRTS library by using the RDRAND instruction. However, in the Intel(R) SGX
simulation environment, this function still generates pseudo random numbers because RDRAND may not be available on the hardware platform.
delivery_mitm_justification: All releases and git tags are PGP signed. Also, most contributors to the library sign their commits. The website is only available over HTTPS or SSH.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: Only insecure sample credentials are provided for testing purposes.
english_justification: The working language of the project is English.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
implementation_languages: C++, Shell, C, Makefile, M4, CMake, Batchfile, Python, Java, Dockerfile, Brainfuck
sites_password_security_justification: No authentication needed for external users.

The project uses the Keep a changelog recommendations available at https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/

The changelog of the project is available at https://github.com/gabor-boros/hammurabi/blob/master/CHANGELOG.rst
release_notes_vulns_justification: We had no CVE reports yet. If there will be any, every fix will be represented in https://github.com/gabor-boros/hammurabi/blob/master/CHANGELOG.rst

The tool used for building is https://python-poetry.org/
build_floss_tools_justification: The project can be built by any standard python build tool.
warnings_justification: Several linters used for static code analyzis
warnings_fixed_justification: Warnings are not required to be fixed but strongly recommended
warnings_strict_justification: Python has no concept compiler warning flags. All the warnings are handled by the tools used and can be mitigated through their config
crypto_published_justification: No cryptographic protocols or algorithms are used
crypto_call_justification: No cryptographic protocols or algorithms are used
crypto_floss_justification: No cryptographic protocols or algorithms are used

crypto_random_justification: No cryptographic protocols or algorithms are used
delivery_mitm_justification: The pull requests opened by the project are using HTTPS API endpoint of GitHub.
static_analysis_justification: code climate, mypy, pylint, flake8, bandit
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Tool used for checking not secure code is bandit, for vulnerability issues we use GitHub's built in solution: https://github.com/gabor-boros/hammurabi/network/alerts
crypto_weaknesses_justification: No cryptographic protocols or algorithms are used
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: The build system is available at https://travis-ci.org/gabor-boros/hammurabi

english_justification: The documentation is provided in English and the language of the project (including issues and pull requests) is English too.

documentation_basics_justification: https://gitlab.com/pastebinrun/pastebinrun/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
repo_public_justification: https://gitlab.com/pastebinrun/pastebinrun
version_semver_justification: The plan is to use Semantic Versioning once the project gets installable with cargo install
version_tags_justification: The plan is to use Semantic Versioning once the project gets installable with cargo install
release_notes_justification: This is software for a single website and it employs continuous delvery.
release_notes_vulns_justification: There are no publicly known vulnerabilities.
warnings_strict_justification: Using cargo defaults, which are sufficiently strict, no need to enable extra strict flags. There is cargo clippy for additional linting.
crypto_published_justification: Random number generation is using ChaCha block cipher with 20 rounds
crypto_pfs_justification: There is no need for key agreement in this project.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: There are no such dependencies as far as I'm aware.
discussion_justification: https://gitlab.com/pastebinrun/pastebinrun/issues
crypto_tls12_justification: The software doesn't "support" TLS, this is intended to be a responsibility of HTTP server such as nginx.
hardened_site_justification: // One or more of the required security hardening headers is missing.
build_standard_variables_justification: Using standard Rust build system, cargo, so I'm assuming there is a way to do so.
build_preserve_debug_justification: Using standard Rust build system, cargo, so I'm assuming there is a way to do so.
dependency_monitoring_justification: Using WhiteSource Renovate to use newest dependencies, and also using cargo audit.
interfaces_current_justification: Warnings are fixed (including depreciation warnings) if they occur
implement_secure_design_justification: The application is designed with security in mind, using language designed for security in mind, searching for vulnerabilities, trying to avoid vulnerabilities by using an ORM for database and a template engine, security HTTP headers are set, and so on.
input_validation_justification: Everything uses a whitelist of allowed values.

name: stdgpu
description: stdgpu: Efficient STL-like Data Structures on the GPU
description_good_justification: The README file (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/blob/master/README.md) provides a description of the project's goals and features.
interact_justification: The project uses GitHub's issue and pull request functionality. Detailed information can also be found in the CONTRIBUTING file (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).
contribution_justification: A file is provided which explains the contribution process (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).
contribution_requirements_justification: The CONTRIBUTING file (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) contains requirements for acceptable contributions.
license_location_justification: The LICENSE file can be found at https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/blob/master/LICENSE.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: A detailed documentation of the project can found at https://stotko.github.io/stdgpu/.
documentation_interface_justification: The full API documentation can be found at https://stotko.github.io/stdgpu/.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: The branch for interim development is the "master" branch. Releases are created from this branch.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: See the current list of releases at https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/releases.
version_tags_justification: Every release is also tagged, see https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/tags.
release_notes_vulns_justification: Vulnerabilities will be tracked in the release notes. Up to now, there was not the need to do so.
report_tracker_justification: The project uses GitHub's issue tracker (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/issues).
report_process_justification: Bug reports can be submitted through GitHub's issue functionality (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/issues).
report_responses_justification: All received bug reports received a timely response.
enhancement_responses_justification: All received enhancement requests received a timely response.
report_archive_justification: Issues in the GitHub tracker (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/issues) are archived and searchable.
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: No vulnerabilities are reported so far. Future ones that got fixed will be reported in the respective release (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/releases).
build_justification: The project uses CMake for building (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt) and also a description of he required tools as well as of the set of convenience scripts in the README (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/blob/master/README.md).
build_common_tools_justification: The project requires CMake as well as a standard C++ compiler for building (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt).
build_floss_tools_justification: The project requires CMake as well as a standard C++ compiler for building (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt). Depending on the used backend, there may be further requirements for building.
test_justification: The project contains a test suite which is released under the same license.
test_invocation_justification: The tests can be build using the same tools as for the project itself. The set provided convenience scripts helps to build and execute them but are not strictly required (see https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/blob/master/README.md).
test_most_justification: The test suite covers most of the project code, see https://codecov.io/gh/stotko/stdgpu.
test_policy_justification: Tests for new functionality should be added. More information can be found at https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md.
tests_are_added_justification: Code coverage of new functionality is tracked with every commit and pull request, see https://codecov.io/gh/stotko/stdgpu.
tests_documented_added_justification: The CONTRIBUTING file (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) documents this policy.
warnings_justification: The project uses common compiler warning flags to build its test suite.
warnings_fixed_justification: The project tries to fix all generated warnings to enable clean and safe builds.
warnings_strict_justification: The project tries to enable as many warnings as possible to cover common errors.
know_secure_design_justification: Patrick Stotko is the primary developer of the library.
know_common_errors_justification: Vulnerabilities for the library includes handling of user input data to the provided data structures. A large test suite as well as the definition and usage of pre- and post-conditions through assertions is employed to minimize the attack surface and detect errors.
delivery_mitm_justification: Releases are distributed through GitHub via https.
delivery_unsigned_justification: Releases are distributed through GitHub via https.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: There are currently no known vulnerabilities.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: There are currently no known vulnerabilities.
static_analysis_justification: The project uses Coverity Quality Analyzer, see https://scan.coverity.com/projects/stotko-stdgpu, as well as cppcheck.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: The project uses Coverity Quality Analyzer, see https://scan.coverity.com/projects/stotko-stdgpu, as well as cppcheck.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: All discovered vulnerabilities have been addressed by either a respective fix or classified as an false positive.
static_analysis_often_justification: Continuous Integration uses cppcheck for code analysis on every contribution.
dynamic_analysis_justification: The projects uses automatic code coverage tracking as a tool for dynamic analysis, see https://codecov.io/gh/stotko/stdgpu.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: The projects defines pre- and post-conditions through assertions and makes extensive use of them.
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: Up to now, no vulnerabilities have been discovered.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Continuous integration is used with GitHub Actions for Linux and Windows, see https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/actions.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: The project is written in English and issues as well as pull requests are accepted in English.
crypto_used_network_justification: The project does not use network communication.
crypto_tls12_justification: The project does not use TLS.
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: The project does not use TLS.
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: The project does not use TLS.
hardened_site_justification: The project is hosted on GitHub (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu) which is known to meet this requirement.
installation_common_justification: CMake is used to properly install the library after building.
build_reproducible_justification: The project is automatically build using Continuous integration tools, see https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/actions.
documentation_current_justification: The documentation of latest release is provided at https://stotko.github.io/stdgpu/. Documentation errors are tracked in the same way as regular bug reports.
documentation_achievements_justification: All achievements are presented at the project's website, see https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu.
sites_password_security_justification: The project does not store passwords.
maintenance_or_update_justification: All released version are available at https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/releases.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: No vulnerabilities have been reported by users in the last 12 months.
coding_standards_justification: The STYLE GUIDE file (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/blob/master/STYLE_GUIDE.md) documents the required style for the project and all contributions.
coding_standards_enforced_justification: clang-format is used to automatically enforce the coding style.
build_standard_variables_justification: CMake is used for building and honors all specified compiler and linker settings.
build_preserve_debug_justification: CMake is used for building and honors all specified compiler and linker settings.
build_non_recursive_justification: The project does not have any cross-dependencies in subdirectories.
installation_standard_variables_justific: CMake honors the specified installation location.
installation_development_quick_justifica: The set of convenience scripts also includes a script to execute installation through CMake.
interfaces_current_justification: The project does not use any deprecated or obsolete functions and quickly ports to alternatives once used functions become obsolete or deprecated.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: The test suite is executed on every pull request and commit to the development branch using Continuous Integration tools.
test_statement_coverage80_justification: Code coverage is tracked at https://codecov.io/gh/stotko/stdgpu. Test coverage significantly exceeds the requirement of 80%.
crypto_algorithm_agility_justification: The project does not use any cryptographic algorithms.
crypto_credential_agility_justification: The project does not store credentials.
copyright_per_file_justification: Each source file (see https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/tree/master/src/stdgpu) contains a copyright statement.
license_per_file_justification: Each source file (see https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/tree/master/src/stdgpu) contains a license statement.
code_review_standards_justification: The code review process is described in the CONTRIBUTING file (https://github.com/stotko/stdgpu/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).
test_statement_coverage90_justification: The code coverage is computed using LCOV and automatically tracked at https://codecov.io/gh/stotko/stdgpu. The code coverage exceeds the requirement of 90%.
